column6: Ionizing radiation classified by the material entity which generates or emits it.
Radiation originating outside the Earth's atmosphere.
Radiation produced on Earth or on another planetary body by natural or artificial means.
column8: One of the principal sources of ground radiation is radon gas.

column6: Material presenting, when irradiated, interaction properties similar to those of soft tissue.
An atomic nucleus, fully stripped of its orbital electrons, and containing 2, 3, 4, 5, or 6 protons.
A radiation measuring device which records dose at the time of detection, with data available in real time
column8: Ionization chambers and silicon solid state detectors can be used as active dosimeters.

column6: A radiation measuring device which integrates the amount of radiation to which it is exposed. Passive detectors are  interrogated at a later time to determine the dose.
column8: Thermoluminescent dosimeters and plastic nuclear track detectors are passive detectors.

column6: The amount of radiation to which a member of the population on Earth is exposed from natural sources, such as terrestrial radiation from naturally-occurring radionuclides in the soil, cosmic radiation originating in outer space, and naturally-occurring ra

The sum of the equivalent doses to all organs in the body, each adjusted to account for the sensitivity of the organ to radiation. Effective dose is calculated for the whole body. Effective dose is expressed in millisieverts (mSv).
column8: The effective dose was calculated to be 300 mSv.

column6: The process of exposing the same sample to more than one type and/or energy of radiation, in sequence or simultaneously.
column8: The samples were exposed to a mixed radiation field consisting of several ions at different energies.

column6: Radiation classified by where the exposure to the radiation is occurring.
That part of the Earth exposed to the Earth atmosphere.
The region between the Earth's surface and an altitude of approximately 100 km
The region of outer space between the Earth's atmosphere and the innermost Earth radiation belt
That part of outer space beyond the Earth's radiation belts.
A radiation dose administered in two or more exposures at specified time intervals
A unit of absorbed dose equal to 1/1000 of a rad
The product of the mean absorbed dose in an organ or tissue and the radiation weighting factor (w_R )of the radiation type of interest
column8: The equivalent dose was calculated to be 300 mSv.

column6: The absorbed radiation dose administered in a single one of a series comprising a fractionated radiation exposure
column8: The total dose was administered in five dose fractions.

column6: Penetrating ionizing radiation, both particulate and electromagnetic, that originates in outer space
Galactic cosmic radiation consists of high-energy charged particles originating from outside the solar system
column8: Galactic cosmic radiation is one of the principal sources of radiation dose outside low-earth orbit

column6: Solar cosmic radiation is high-energy charged particles that originate from the sun.
column8: Solar cosmic radiation contributes to the radiation dose to humans in space.

column6: The measurement datum representing a dose to an organism or object per unit time.
column8: The dose rate was 0.5 mGy/min.

column6: Vehicles, crewed or uncrewed, which are designed to orbit about the Earth or another celestial body or be placed into a trajectory to another celestial body or location in space.
column8: The Apollo spacecraft took 24 astronauts to the Moon between 1968 and 1972.

column6: a self-contained unit of a spacecraft
A self-contained unit of the International Space Station.
column8: The experiment was conducted in the International Space Station module Columbus|The experiment was conducted on the Russian module of the ISS.

column6: A spacecraft capable of supporting a human crew in orbit for an extended period of time. It lacks major propulsion or landing systems. Stations must have docking ports to allow other spacecraft to dock to transfer crew and supplies.
column8: Mir was a space station that operated in low Earth orbit from 1986 to 2001, operated by the Soviet Union and later by Russia.

column6: The path leading from a particle accelerator to an experimental station used in experiments in particle physics, materials science, chemistry, and molecular biology, or in irradiation tests or to produce isotopes.
column8: The HIMAC accelerator has a beamline dedicated for radiation biology experiments.

column6: Radiation produced by a particle accelerator.
Radiation produced by a nuclear reactor.
High energy photons emitted during nuclear decay of the Cesium-137 isotope.
High energy photons emitted during nuclear decay of the Cobalt-60 isotope.
High energy photons emitted during nuclear decay of the Cobalt-57 isotope.
Electromagnetic radiation with photon energies approximately 3-120 eV. High energy UV radiation can be ioinizing.
Neutrons or charged particles, such as protons or alpha particles that produce ionizing events densely spaced on a molecular scale (e.g., >10 keV-micron^[-1].
X and gamma rays or light charged particles such as electrons that produce sparse ionizing events far apart on a molecular scale.
Electromagnetic radiation having sufficient energy to remove one or more electrons from an atom
A device that is used to measure the amount of ionizing radiation exposure or absorption.
Particle or electromagnetic radiation with sufficient energy to liberate one or more electrons from an atom.
Charged particles with kinetic energy imparted by natural or artificial means (such as by a particle accelerator)
electromagnetic radiation with photon energies greater than approximately 100 keV
A device used to impart kinetic energy to subatomic particles by means of electric and magnetic fields
A device in which nuclear fission may be initiated and controlled in a self-sustaining chain reaction to generate energy or produce useful radiation.
Atomic nuclei, with atomic number 2 or greater and kinetic energy imparted by natural or artificial means
Atomic nuclei, variously defined as having atomic number 2, 3, 4, 5 or 6 and kinetic energy imparted by natural or artificial means
A particle with a positive or negative electric charge
Activity carried out by crewed or robotic vehicles outside the Earth's atmmosphere.

A principle of radiation protection philosophy that requires that exposures to ionizing radiation be kept as low as reasonably achievable, economic and social factors being taken into account. The protection from radiation exposure is ALARA when the expen
column8: One of the measures to ensure ALARA is to minimize the time spent working around radioactive materials.

column6: The reduction of radiation intensity upon passage of radiation through matter
column8: Attenuation in concrete or leadshielding is a common method of radiation protection on Earth, but is impractical in space due to mass constraints.

column6: Use of a biological response as an indicator of a dose of an effective agent (e.g., the extent of decline in peripheral blood lymphocytes of humans exposed to ionizing radiation can be used as an indicator of the absorbed dose to the whole body from that
column8: Biodosimetry was used to measure the exposure of some victims of the Chernobyl nuclear accident.

column6: The term used to describe the effects on cells in proximity to irradiated cells, but through which radiation has not passed. In experimental radiation biology, the bystander effect can be investigated  by targeting individual cells, or by using doses low enough that the probability for a given cell to be hit by a particle is less than one.
column8: The bystander effect can be  studied by identifying cells that were traversed by a charged particle.

column6: Highly energetic electrons produced during inelastic collisions between ionizing radiation and atomic electrons. In a small proportion of collisions, the ejected electron receives a considerable amount of energy (i.e., >1,000 eV), allowing it to travel a
column8: Delta ray energies increase with the velocity of the incident particle.

column6: The product of the absorbed dose (D) at a point and the quality factor (Q) at that point for the radiation type (i.e., H = DQ). The unit of H is J-kg^[-1] with the special name sievert (Sv)
column8: The average annual dose equivalent for crew members on the ISS is approximately 300 mSv.

column6: The increased risk from induced cancer due to exposure when the effects over an entire lifetime are accounted for. Individuals who would have died of cancer anyway but die early because of exposure are not included
Neutrons of energies above a few hundred kiloelectron volts (keV)
column8: The sample was irradiated with fast neutrons.

column6: The number of particles or photons per unit of cross-sectional area perpendicular to the direction of the particle (units of m^2 or cm^2) (i.e., particles-m^[-2] or particles-cm^[-2]).
column8: The value of the fluence was approximately 1 particle per cm2.

column6: The quotient of dN by dt, where dN is the increment of the particle number in the time interval dt. The unit for flux is reciprocal second (s^[-1].)
column8: The flux of cosmic ray muons per cm2 at the surface of the Earth is approximately 1.0.

column6: An atomic nucleus, fully stripped of its orbital electrons, containing 2 or more protons. Nuclei containing between 2 protons (helium) and 6 protons (carbon) are sometimes referred to as light ions.
column7: In RBO--needs def from NCRP Glossary (https://ncrponline.org/wp-content/themes/ncrp/PDFs/NCRP-Composite-Glossary.pdf)

column6: The energy deposited by an ionizing charged particle or photon in any medium per unit path length.
column8: Biological effects are a function of LET.

column6: The mean absorbed radiation dose  in a specified tissue or organ of the human body.
column8: Radiation protection standards take into account organ dose as well as whole body dose.

column6: Dimensionless factor developed for purposes of radiation protection and assessing health risks in general terms that accounts for the relative biological effectiveness of different radiations in producing stochastic effects and is used to relate absorbed
column8: Neutrons have a high quality factor compared to photons.

column6: A measurement datum of the quantity of radiation absorbed by a substance or organism. The term "radiation dose" may for example refer to absorbed dose, organ dose, dose equivalent or equivalent dose, depending upon context and weighting factor(s).
column8: The samples received a dose of 1 Gy. (The use of the gray unit implies that "dose" refers to a measured quantity, typically absorbed dose or organ dose.)|The samples received a dose of 1 Sv. (The use of the sievert unit implies that "dose" refers to a der

column6: Currently under discussion: [A general term referring to the relative biological effectiveness of the radiation of interest. For example, the absorbed dose from an exposure to neutron radiation may be quantitatively the same as that from an exposure to ga
column8: Radiation quality has been commonly expressed in terms of the LET of the ionizing particles that deliver the absorbed dose. (Rossi, 1959)

column6: A factor used to allow for differences in the biological effectiveness between different radiations when calculating equivalent dose (H_T) (see equivalent dose). These factors are independent of the tissue or organ irradiated.
column8: Radiation weighting factors may change as more data on biological effects are obtained.

column6: Factor used to compare the biological effectiveness of absorbed doses from different types of ionizing radiation, determined experimentally. RBE is the ratio of the absorbed dose of a reference radiation to the absorbed dose of the radiation in question r
column8: Neutrons have been found to have a higher RBE than electrons.

column6: Denotes a substance with absorbing and scattering properties for a given radiation that sufficiently match those of a particular biological tissue.
column8: Tissue equivalent materials can be used to study radiation effects at depth in the human body.

column6: The  amount of energy from any type of ionizing radiation deposited in a specified mass of any medium.
The  amount of energy from any type of ionizing radiation deposited in a specified mass of any medium per unit time.
The kinetic energy carried by a particle or photon of ionizing radiation.
Electromagnetic radiation with photon energies approximately between 0.1 and 120 keV. The upper end of the x-ray spectrum overlaps with the lower end of the gamma ray spectrum.
A material entity which emits radiation
A protocol in which a sample is kept under conditions identical to irradiated samples, without exposure
A protocol for administering a total radiation dose in two or more increments separated by a specified time interval
The region of space between the Earth and the Moon
A region of space defined by a regular, repeating path of a specified object about Earth's moon
The area of the lunar landmass exposed to space
The region of space between the Earth and Mars
A region of space defined by a regular, repeating path of a specified object about Mars
The area of the Mars landmass exposed to the Martian atmosphere
The region of space in the Solar System between planets
The outermost solid or liquid area of a planet
An organism or material entity kept unexposed to radiation, for purposes of comparison to a similar organism or material entity that has been exposed to radiation
A study at a ground facility designed so as to replicate one or more conditions in space (e.g. radiation, microgravity, isolation)

An study at a ground facility designed so as to replicate conditions in space (e.g. radiation, microgravity, isolation) with the exception of one condition, so as to ascertain the effects of that condition on an organism or instrument
A protocol for administering radiation to a sample
One of the series of individual doses administered to a sample in a fractionated irradiation.
Time between fractions in a fractionated irradiation.
The region of the atmosphere above 8000 feet above sea level. Altitudes above 12000 feet are sometimes referred to as very high altitude, and above 18000 feet as extremely high altitude.
A radiation quality resulting from a material entity being kept under similar conditions as an irradiated material entity
An aircraft which flies a series of parabolic arcs to simulate micrgravity.
An aircraft which flies at altitudes greater than commercial aircraft altitudes for research purposes.
An research aircraft designed to operate without crew members, either autonomously or under control from a ground station
Fully ionized atomic nuclei with 2 or more protons and energies in excess of tens of MeV per nucleon
A study of a response to radiation conditioned by prior administration of radiation of a different type and/or at a different dose or dose rate
The total dose administered in a series of radiation fractions divided by the elapsed time between the beginning of the first exposure fraction and the end of the last exposure fraction
A device which exposes samples to gamma radiation.
The electric charge of a particle used in an irradiation
The measurement of the amount of radiation taken up by a sample.

A microbeam is a narrow beam of radiation, of micrometer or sub-micrometer dimensions. Together with integrated imaging techniques, microbeams allow precisely defined quantities of damage to be introduced at precisely defined locations.
